                                                                                                                                         290. To make Touch-paper.
                                                                                                                            Dissolve   in some spirits of wine or vinegar, a little
                                                                                                                          saltpetre; then take some purple or bine paper, wet it
                                                                                                                          « nh the above liquor, and when dry it win be fit for use.

                                                                                                                          196       PHILOSOPHICAL RECREATIONS,
                                                                                                                          When you paste this paper on any of your works, take
                                                                                                                          care that the paste does not touch that part which is to
                                                                                                                          burn. The method of using this paper is, by cutting it
                                                                                                                          into slips, long enough to go once round the mouth of the
                                                                                                                          serpent, cracker, &c. When you paste on these slips,
                                                                                                                          leave a little above the mouth of the case not pasted;
                                                                                                                          then prime the rase with meut pourder, and twist the
                                                                                                                          paper to a point.
                                                                                                                                   291.   Of   the vertical Scrole Wheel.
                                                                                                                            This wheel     may be made of any diameter, but must
                                                                                                                          be constructed thus : — Have a block of a moderate size,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-26 16:55 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066413034
                                                                                                                          into which fix four flat spokes, and on them fix a fiat
                                                                                                                          circular fell of wood. Round the front of this fell place
                                                                                                                          port-fires ; then, on the front of the spokes form a scrole,
                                                                                                                          either with a hoop or strong iron wire ; on this scrole tie
                                                                                                                          cases of brilliant fire, in proportion to the wheel, head to
                                                                                                                          tail. When you fire this wheel, light the first case near
                                                                                                                          the fell ; then, as the cases tire successively, you will see
                                                                                                                          the circle of fire gradually diminish ; but whether the
                                                                                                                          illuminations on the fell begin with the scrole or not, is
                                                                                                                          immaterial.

                                                                                                                             Sparks when rammed into choaked Cases.
                                                                                                                             The  set colours of fire produced by sparks are divided
                                                                                                                          into four sorts, viz. the black, white, grey, and red; the
                                                                                                                          black charges are composed of two ingredients, which

                                                                                                                          saltpetre, sulphur, and charcoal ; the grey of four, via.
                                                                                                                          meal powder, saltpetre, brimstone, and charcoal ; and
                                                                                                                          the red   of   three, viz. meal    ponder, charcoal, and   saw
                                                                                                                          dust.
                                                                                                                            There are, besides these four regular or set charges,
                                                                                                                          two others, which are distinguished by the names of
                                                                                                                                                   ¦1

                                                                                                                          compound and brilliant charges ; the compound charge

                                                                                                                          saltpetre, brimstone, charcoal, saw-dust, sea-coal, an

                                                                                                                                                  298.   Of   Saltpetre.
                                                                                                                             Saltpetre
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-26 16:55 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066413034
                                                                                                                                         being the principal ingredient in fire works,
                                                                                                                          and a volatile body, by reason of its inflammable and
                                                                                                                          aerial parts, is easily rarified by fire ; but not so soon
                                                                                                                          when foul and gross, as when purified from its crude and
                                                                                                                          earthy parts, which greatly retard its velocity : there
                                                                                                                          fore, when any quantity of fire-works is intended to be
                                                                                                                          made, it would be necessary first to examine the salt
                                                                                                                          petre ; for if it be not well cleansed from all impurities,
                                                                                                                          ind of a good sort, your works will not have their proper
                                                                                                                          effect.
                                                                                                                                           299.    To pulverize Saltpetre.
                                                                                                                            Take    a copper kettle the bottom being spherical, anil
                                                                                                                          put into it fourteen pounds of refined saltpetre, with two
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          quarts or five pints of clean water ; then put the kettle
                                                                                                                          on a slow fire, and when the saltpetre is dissolved,  if  any
                                                                                                                          impurities arise,   skim  them   oft', and   keep constantly
                                                                                                                          stirring it with two large sticks till all the water exhales.
                                                                                                                          When done enough, it will appear like white sand, and
                                                                                                                          as fine as flour ; but if it should boil too fast,
                                                                                                                                                                               take the
                                                                                                                          kettle off the fire, and set it on some wet
                                                                                                                                                                           sand, which

                                                                                                                                       OR, WINTER AMUSEMENTS.                        1   99
                                                                                                                          will prevent   the saltpetre from sticking to the kettle.
                                                                                                                          When you have pulverized a quantity, be careful to keep
                                                                                                                          it in a dry place, not exposed to the air.
                                                                                                                                         300.    To     make Crackers.
                                                                                                                            Cut   some stout cartridge paper into pieces,           three
                                                                                                                          inches and a half broad, and one foot long ; fold         down
                                                                                                                          one edge of each of these pieces lengthwise, about        three
                                                                                                                          quarters of an inch broad ; then fold the double           edge
                                                                                                                          down a quarter of an inch, and turn the single edge        back
                                                                                                                          half over the double fold.  Open it, and lay all along the
                                                                                                                          channel which is formed by the folding of the paper, some
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-26 16:55 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066413034
                                                                                                                          meal powder ; then fold it over and over till the paper is
                                                                                                                          doubled up, rubbing it down every turn ; this being done,
                                                                                                                          bend it backwards and forwards, two inches and a half,
                                                                                                                          or thereabouts, at a time, as often as the paper will allow.
                                                                                                                          Hold all these folds flat and close, and with a small
                                                                                                                          pinching cord, give one turn round the middle of the
                                                                                                                          cracker, and pinch it close ; bind it with packthread,
                                                                                                                          as tight as you can : then in the place where it was
                                                                                                                          pinched, prime one end, and cap it with touch paper.
                                                                                                                          When these crackers are fired, they will give a report at
                                                                                                                          every turn of the paper; if you would have a great
                                                                                                                          number of bounces, you must cut the paper longer, or
                                                                                                                          join them after they are made ; but if they are made very
                                                                                                                          long before they are pinched, you must have a piece of
                                                                                                                                                     deep enough to let in half the
                                                                                                                                                   it it,
                                                                                                                          wood with a groove in
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          cracker ; this will hold   straight while      pinching.

                                                                                                                                     301. To make Squibs and Serpents.
                                                                                                                             First   make the cases,        of about six inches in length,
                                                                                                                          by rolling slips of stout cartridge paper three times round

                                                                                                                          200         PHILOSOPHICAL RECREATIONS, &C.
                                                                                                                          a roller,   and pasting   the  last fold : tying it near the
                                                                                                                          bottom as tigktas possible, and making it air tight at the
                                                                                                                          end by sealing-wax. Then take of gun-powder half a
                                                                                                                          pound, charcoal one ounce, brimstone one ounce, and
                                                                                                                          steel fihngs half an ounce, (or in like proportion), grind
                                                                                                                          tbem with a muller or pound them in a mortar.          Your
                                                                                                                          cases being very dry and ready, first put a thimble-full
                                                                                                                          of your powder, and ram it hard down with a ruler ; then
                                                                                                                          fill the case to the top with the aforesaid mixture, ram
                                                                                                                          ming it bard down in the course of filling two or three
                                                                                                                          times ; when this is done, point it with touch paper,
                                                                                                                          which should be pasted on that part which touches the
                                                                                                                          case, otherwise it is liable to drop off.
